issues.description: The problem statement's plain-text list of attributes uses the names 'inscribedStudents' and 'guestStudents' (line 17), but the UML diagram and the intended implementation use 'numberOfInscribedStudents' and 'numberOfGuestStudents'. This name mismatch between the descriptive text and the UML/tests may confuse students about the exact attribute names they should implement (and which getters/setters/tests will expect).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute names consistent across the problem statement and UML. Update the descriptive text to use the exact attribute names from the UML/tests ('numberOfInscribedStudents' and 'numberOfGuestStudents'), or alter the UML/tests to match the simpler names ('inscribedStudents' and 'guestStudents'). Preferably, update the prose so it matches the UML and test names to avoid student confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement's textual instructions list the attributes as `lectureName`, `inscribedStudents`, `guestStudents`, `numberOfLecturers` and `numberOfTutors` (problem_statement.md lines 16-18), while the UML diagram and the solution implementation use the more explicit names `numberOfInscribedStudents` and `numberOfGuestStudents` (problem_statement.md lines 63-68; solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java lines 6-10). This internal naming mismatch (text vs. UML/solution) can confuse students about the exact attribute names they should implement and the constructor parameter order (the task explicitly asks to follow the UML). Although minor, it forces students to resolve which naming to follow and may cause unnecessary cognitive load when mapping the textual requirements to the code skeleton and final solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute names consistent: update the problem statement textual list to use `numberOfInscribedStudents` and `numberOfGuestStudents` so it matches the UML and solution (or, alternatively, update UML and solution to the shorter names). Prefer aligning the textual instructions to the UML/solution, since the task explicitly asks students to follow the UML (this reduces confusion about constructor parameter order).
